content.match_overview: Crystal Palace host Ipswich Town at Selhurst Park in a Premier League clash with contrasting stakes. Palace (12th) have transformed from relegation candidates to European hopefuls under Oliver Glasner, winning 7 of their last 15 league matches while averaging 2.1 goals/game during this resurgence [1][5]. Ipswich (19th) remain winless in 9 league games, possessing the division's third-worst defensive record (1.8 goals conceded/game) [1][3]. This 22nd competitive meeting sees Palace holding historical dominance (13 wins vs Ipswich's 8) with 65% of goals coming in second halves [3][8]. The reverse fixture saw Palace win 1-0 through Mateta's strike [1].

team_news.raw: Palace's attack suffers a massive blow with Mateta (12 PL goals) ruled out due to a head injury requiring 24+ stitches from their FA Cup win. Midfield general Will Hughes (3.1 tackles/game) serves suspension for yellow card accumulation [1][5]. Ipswich's defensive crisis deepens with Burgess (calf), Tuanzebe (hamstring), and Walton (GK) all unavailable, forcing a makeshift backline. Loanee Kalvin Phillips (50% duel success rate) remains doubtful in midfield [2][5].

home.projected_xi: Henderson; Richards, Lacroix, Guehi; Munoz, Wharton, Lerma, Mitchell; Sarr, Eze; Nketiah

away.projected_xi: Hladky; Clarke, Woolfenden, Edmundson, Davis; Morsy, Luongo; Hutchinson, Chaplin, Broadhead; Hirst

asian_handicap_analysis.analysis: Despite identical odds (1.90), Palace holds clear advantages: 64% implied win probability vs 15% for Ipswich [6]. Glasner's men average 1.8 xG/home game vs Ipswich's 1.1 xGA/away [3][8]. However, 47% of Palace's goals come between 46-60' - a vulnerability if Ipswich parks the bus early [3].
asian_handicap_analysis.raw: Ipswich have failed to cover 0 AH in 78% of away games. Palace's 3-4-2-1 system creates 4.2 crosses/game from wingbacks Munoz/Mitchell - problematic for Ipswich's 6'0" average CB height [1][3]. Value lies in Palace's set-piece threat (12 goals) against Ipswich's aerial weakness (58% duels lost).

key_player_matchups.title: Eze vs Ipswich's Left Channel
key_player_matchups.content: Eze (3 goals, 5 assists) averages 4.7 dribbles/game vs Leif Davis' 1.3 tackles/game. Davis has been dribbled past 2.1 times/90 [3][5].
key_player_matchups.raw: 68% of Eze's attacking actions come through central-left zones - directly testing Davis who's played 90+ minutes in 4 consecutive losses.

key_player_matchups.title: Nketiah's Press vs Morsy's Distribution
key_player_matchups.content: Nketiah (2.3 pressures/90) faces Morsy (82% pass accuracy) in pivot battles. Morsy has 3 errors leading to goals this season [5][8].
key_player_matchups.raw: Morsy's 11.7 long balls/90 could be neutralized by Nketiah's 9.6 km coverage - forcing Ipswich to build through Palace's press (6.3 PPDA).

betting_insights.insight: Palace have 64% implied probability (1.48 odds) vs Ipswich's 15% (7.13)
betting_insights.raw: 11 of Palace's 15 wins came against bottom-half teams. Ipswich have lost 73% of games vs top-14 sides [1][6].

betting_insights.insight: Palace games average 3.1 total goals (59% Over) vs Ipswich's 2.8 (54% Over)
betting_insights.raw: 6 of Palace's last 9 had Over 2.5. Ipswich conceded 2+ in 7/10 away games [3][5].

betting_insights.insight: BTTS hit in 61% of Palace home games vs 53% for Ipswich away
betting_insights.raw: Ipswich score in 67% of away games despite losses. Palace kept 3 clean sheets in 15 home matches [3][8].

prediction.reasoning: Palace's midfield control (56% possession last 5) should overwhelm Ipswich's depleted defense. Eze/Sarr's creativity (4.3 key passes/90 combined) targets Ipswich's left flank weakness. However, Hirst's physicality (6 aerial wins/90) could exploit Palace's 3-CB system missing Ward's experience. Final 30-minute fatigue from Palace's high press (113km/90) leaves room for Ipswich consolation.

content.raw_perplexity_content:
<think>
Okay, I need to create a detailed betting analysis for the Crystal Palace vs Ipswich Premier League match on March 8, 2025. Let me start by going through the search results provided.

First, looking at the team news. Crystal Palace has some key injuries. Jean-Philippe Mateta is out with a head injury, and Will Hughes is suspended. They also have long-term injuries like Chadi Riad and Cheick Doucoure. Their probable lineup is a 3-4-2-1 with Nketiah replacing Mateta.

For Ipswich, defensive injuries are a problem. Cameron Burgess, Axel Tuanzebe, and Christian Walton are out. Kalvin Phillips is a maybe, and they have several attackers missing. Their lineup might struggle defensively.

Head-to-head stats from [3] and [8] show Palace has a better record, with 13 wins to Ipswich's 8. Recent form from [1] and [5] indicates Palace is on a three-game winning streak, while Ipswich hasn't won a league game since December.

The Asian handicap analysis is tricky. The line is 0 with both teams at 1.90. But Palace is at home and in better form. However, some sources like [4] suggest Ipswich might have value. But considering Palace's recent form and home advantage, maybe Palace is the safer bet.

Key player matchups: Palace's Eze and Sarr against Ipswich's weakened defense. Also, Nketiah stepping in for Mateta could be crucial. For Ipswich, Jack Clarke is a key attacker, but their defense is depleted.

Betting insights: Over 2.5 goals seems likely based on Palace's scoring trends [5][6]. Both teams to score is also possible as Palace's defense isn't airtight.

Final score prediction: Palace 2-1 Ipswich with moderate confidence, around 7/10. That aligns with [5] and [7], where Chris Sutton predicted 1-0 but some others suggest higher scores.

I need to structure all this into the required JSON format, making sure each section is filled with data from the sources. Also, validate the stats and ensure all 'raw' fields have detailed insights. Check for injuries, suspensions, and how they impact each team's performance. Make sure the Asian handicap analysis considers form, H2H, and team news.
